abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Project Performance Audit
            Report (PPAR) on the Fourth Railway Project, on the Fifth
            Railway Project, and on the Kosovo Railway Project. For all
            three projects, inception was fast and preparation
            problematic. Differences of opinion between the Bank and the
            Borrower regarding objectives complicated both the
            preparation and implementation phases, and led to
            non-achievement of financial targets.  None of the three
            projects benefitted from the experience of  preceding ones
            partly because haste to proceed with the next lending
            operation did not allow time for reflection, and partly
            because neither the Bank nor the Borrower were convinced
            that study of the past is useful in planning the future.
            Little importance was attached to in-house review and,
            indeed, it was the Bank who advised CYR, and CYR took the
            advice that preparation of Project Completion report (PCRs)
            ought to be done by outside consultants. The fact remains
            that PCR preparation is an educational experience for those
            who prepare them and this experience was lost to CYR and to
            the Railway Transport Enterprise (RTEs). By the same token,
            the leisurely, and somewhat too generous, editing in EMENA
            of the Borrower's draft PCRs, demonstrates the limited
            significance attached to lesson-learned from past mistakes.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Kosovo Railway Project results may
            be summarized as follow: The project achieved its basic
            objectives of modernizing the railway facilities of Kosovo.
            However, the time taken to complete the project was over
            seven years compared to the original timetable of three
            years. On the management side, improvements were
            successfully implemented in freight operations. The
            management reorganization was completed at the end of the
            project period so it is too early to evaluate its impact.
            Most of the operational and financial targets set under the
            loan were not achieved due mainly to: (i) delays in project
            implementation; (ii) a fall in freight traffic; and (iii)
            Government failure to authorize adequate tariff increases
            during a period of high inflation. The overall evaluation of
            the project is that it was marginally successful and that
            the benefits will be sustained in the future. As in many
            other railway projects, the Bank's expectations on the
            financial performance were too optimistic. One of the main
            causes of the poor financial performance has been the
            Government's reluctance to raise railway tariffs to
            compensate for rising costs at a time of rapid domestic
            inflation. The PCR confirms the lessons drawn from previous
            railway projects in Yugoslavia which demonstrated the need
            for allowing sufficient time for implementation. Like
            previous projects, this too illustrates the difficulties in
            securing compliance with covenants to improve operating
            efficiency and financial objectives and in recruitment of
            qualified staff. Finally, it shows that institutional
            development ought to be undertaken during a time frame much
            longer than that of one Bank-financed project.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Kosovo Railway Project comprises the
            1981-83 slice of the Investment Plan of RTO Pristina aimed
            at improving the capacity and efficiency of the railway
            network in Kosovo, the weakest part of the Yugoslav system.
            The principal components are: (a) the reconstruction of
            Kosovo Junction; (b) the installation of modern signaling
            and telecommunications on the Lesak-Djeneral Jankovic main
            line; (c) the procurement of rolling stock and integrated
            transport equipment; and (d) training and technical
            assistance to improve management, planning and freight
            operations. The main project objectives are to improve RTO
            Pristina's management and operational capabilities in
            order: (a) to improve the capacity and efficiency of the
            Kosovo rail network; and (b) to facilitate the development
            and exploitation of Kosovo's abundant mineral resources
            which generate long distance bulk traffic, thereby
            accelerating the economic growth of the less developed
            Kosovo region.
